title: ​Tom Pegden goes in a driverless car at MIRA | Leicester Mercury
text:
Comments (0) 
There was nothing particularly worrying when the driver took her hands off the wheel and put the car into driverless mode, writes Mercury business editor Tom Pegden. 
It helped that the driver was Amy Rimmer, the JLR (Jaguar Land Rover) research engineer who had helped programme the technology being used behind the dashboard. 
It also helped it was a very comfortable Land Rover, with all the modern safety systems you might expect. 
Cruising at a steady 51mph, the car made easy work of the test track at the MIRA research facility at Higham-on-the-Hill, near Hinckley. 
If she had wanted, she could have taken out a newspaper and done a crossword – the car was perfectly capable of driving itself and warning her if anything came up ahead. 
When the car in front slowed down, it indicated and overtook. If there was a car in its blind spot it happily waited. 
And when Amy failed to take back control after it asked her to, it worked out something was wrong and came to a gradual halt. 
It the real world, it would even have called 999 to tell them there was a potential emergency – no less than you might expect if it had been the hard shoulder of the M1. 
The technology worked and it needs to because within a year these cars, or ones very similar, will be tested on the streets of Coventry and Milton Keynes. 
OPINION: The Brexit rollercoaster rattles on 
A lot of the safety elements of driverless cars are already there – cameras, wireless technology, clever computer, algorithms, radar systems, you name it. 
One of the next big steps – and one of the big points of media days like this and the future real world trials – is getting the message out there that the technology is safe. 
If the cars on display at this south Leicestershire test track were anything to go by, that might not be half as difficult as you might imagine.
